utterances: But the intention will be that Britain's new I.D.
card, will enable it to join that band of countries, that simply accepted the I.D.
card as a valid travel document within Europe.
In your belief, is there anyway that the industry and the country are going to be ready for this by 2008?
Well, I don't see that it is impossible.
But I think that from my view of situation, the requirement as to what it is the government wants to implement, within a particularly time scale, needs to be very clearly set out.
And I think it's this that's causing the confusion in the estimates of potential costs.
Mm-hmm.
Because on the one hand, the bill covers a huge set of aspirations for what I.D.
cards could do.
For example, you present your I.D.
card for opening a bank account, for getting insurance to prove your identity.
And there would need to be terminals in places, so that every place could have a biometric reader that would enable you to give a sample if that transaction required it.
Now, that's not a hundred percent clear as to what kind of transactions would need that level of security.
Aren't there also questions of, if there is injury, or something like that, your voiceprint, your facial presentation, your, even your iris presentation might change?
Okay.
Voiceprints certainly won't be used in this particular, this particular I.D.
card.
Focusing on face, fingerprint, and iris.
Uh-huh.
And the intention really is, is to collect enough data to be pretty sure that some combination of that data will give you enough possibilities to make it work.
Mm-hmm.
So, for example, if you only had face on there, you could be pretty certain that it's going to fail.
But you have combination of several fingers, iris, and face, or some combination of those, the probability look that you could accommodate the kind of population that Britain has.
However, as I said earlier, no real trials have been done to prove that that's the case.
Hmm.
Martin George, thanks very much.
Thank you.
Martin George, a consultant for I.D.
Craft, a British consultancy service focusing on application of authentication technologies.
He is with us from his home in Bristol in England.
Well, do you use biometric measurements where you work or where you go to school?
Do they work for you?
800-989-8255, 800-989-TALK, our e-mail address is talk@npr.org, and let's talk with Jeff.
Jeff's calling us from Chicago.
Hi, we're in the adult entertainment industry.
We have six locations in the Midwest and in Texas and we use fingerprinting to ID our dancers.
We've been doing it for two years now and we're now beginning to bring all employees on line, office staff, wait staff, bartenders, even the kitchen.
Security, so that we know who is in the building.
This way we can log payroll, lot of different reasons, and now we're actually looking into a way of automatically debiting them into either some type of ATM card or directly into their bank accounts.
We're going to try to cut out a payroll department that probably costs a couple thousand dollars a month to operate.
Any problems with it thus far?
The girls might have smudges from makeup on their fingers and sometimes it doesn't read properly.
But it has all their vital information, name, social security number.
It's really been a benefit for us.
Jeff thanks very much.
You're welcome.
Walter Hamilton is Chairman of the International Biometric Industry Association, a non-profit trade association that represents the biometric industry.
He joins us from the studios of member station WUSF in Tampa and it's nice to have you on the program today.
Good afternoon Neal, how are you?
I'm well, thank you.
And as we were just hearing, obviously biometrics in England would be used for a national ID card, in this country it's being used in more and more commercial applications, correct?
That's correct and also in government applications as well.
One of the more exciting applications on the commercial sector would be the growth of the use of fingerprint technology for performing retail purchases at the point of sale.

An example would be at grocery stores or convenience stores or other retail merchants where a person would previously register their fingerprints along with their checking account and other information and so they wouldn't need to carry credit cards or even a checkbook or cash to make a purchase.

They would simply key in, say a telephone number to uniquely select their account and then place their finger on a reader at the point of sale and it would transfer funds from their checking account into the merchant's account, making the transaction fast and inexpensive.
And since this would be a voluntary program, I guess privacy and security concerns, civil liberties concerns, those are by the board.
Well, it would be a voluntary program, but of course, the operators of this system should protect your personal information, as anyone should do in their ordinary course of business.
Mm-hmm.

Hi Neal.
I'm a permanent resident here in the states and I have a super high-tech card.
I guess it used to be called a green card.
But the comment I want to make on it is, unfortunately I still need my Canadian passport to travel everywhere.
I can only use this to enter the states, and I was just wondering if it was, this technology, was going to make, was going to be made international.
Walter Hamilton, I've not heard discussion of that.
There are a number of initiatives regarding international travel documents being associated with the use of biometric technology.

One recent initiative that's been discussed in the press and proposed by the current administration is the use of a slimmed-down version of a passport in the form factor of a card that would be used for travel between Canada and the United States by Canadian citizens and vice versa and between Mexico and United States for example.

It's called the Western Hemisphere Travel Initiative and it would not require a passport for that type of travel, but it would issue a travel card and that card would contain a biometric feature such as a fingerprint.
But if Aggie wanted to go to Costa Rica, she would still have to carry her Canadian passport and this new digital ID card to get back into the US.
If she was a citizen of Canada and a permanent resident of the United States, she probably would need both, but I'm not an expert on those immigration rules.
Well, Aggie, I'm sorry we can't seem to help you.
Okay, thanks.
I love your show.
Thanks very much for the phone call.

Sure.
Let's see if we can go to - this is Ross.
Ross in Oklahoma City.

Well, like any emerging technology market, there are issues that have to do with how the technology is developed and introduced and biometrics in particular, because of the implications for privacy and civil liberty violations, I think is particularly interesting, and some of the areas where I think we really have to look at are, for example, how these large databases are going to be managed.
I happen to feel very strongly that, and probably as most of the civil libertarians do, that large centralized databases with all our information stored in it, probably not a good idea.
